awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Antecedents and Consequences of Disaster-Related Conspiracy Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
A conspiracy theory is the belief that powerful actors are engaging in wide-ranging, black-boxed (often criminal or ambiguously legal) activities for their own political or personal gain. Conspiracy theories often arise in response to large-scale, surprising, negative events as an attempt for people to satisfy epistemic and existential needs for order, certainty, and control that are triggered by the event. Although conspiracy theory beliefs often the result of mundane psychological and strategic processes, they can have negative consequences for democratic governance/accountability, national security, and national health, prosperity, and welfare. Conspiracy theories center on blame attribution and can motivate attitudes and behavior in response to the attribution. As such, they are particularly problematic for democratic governance and accountability.  To examine the effect of public perception of conspiracy theories on electoral outcomes in the aftermath of a major natural disaster, this project surveys a nationally representative sample of 1,000 citizens in a region that has just experienced a major earthquake prior to a national election and 1,000 citizens shortly after the national election. The study advances understanding of the assertion that people who perceive themselves to be on the losing side of politics are more likely to believe conspiracy theories than their counterparts on the winning side of politics.  

The project will survey a nationally representative sample of 1,000 citizens prior to a national election and a second nationally representative sample of 1,000 citizens shortly after the national election. The surveys will be comprised of questions aimed at assessing the extent to which respondents endorse a series of earthquake-related conspiracy theories as well as the antecedents and consequences of conspiracy theory beliefs. A stratified probability sampling frame based on the random selection of districts and neighborhoods/villages as primary sampling units will be used for both the pre- and post-election surveys. Both samples will be weighted to national demographic benchmarks. The proposed project advances our understanding of these consequential beliefs in three ways: (1) it argues that different conspiracy theories can satisfy different motives, and that, therefore the strength of association between commonly-studied antecedents and each conspiracy theory will vary depending on the characteristics of the conspiracy theories themselves, (2) it explores  whether the antecedents and consequences of conspiracy theory beliefs differ before and after a hotly contested, ideologically-charged election, (3) the project's pre/post-election design will enable a direct test the assertion that people who perceive themselves to be on the losing side of politics are more likely to believe conspiracy theories than their counterparts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the age of climate change, we are witnessing more frequent and destructive extreme weather events across the globe, such as severe hurricanes, droughts, wildfires, tsunamis, and earthquakes. In the wake of these natural disasters, unsubstantiated rumors and/or conspiracy theories can flourish. This is because rumors/conspiracy theories spread and are more likely to be believed in the context of an event that is important in people’s lives and when authoritative information about the event is lacking or ambiguous. These types of misinformation are also tempting because they provide a way for people to try to rationalize their emotions in the face of an important, confusing event. In sum, natural disasters are a combination of importance, chaos, ambiguity, and anxiety that can give rise to rumors and conspiracy theories. They shake the sense of an ordered and structured world and instead bring about feelings of uncertainty and powerlessness, making individuals susceptible to both rumors and/or conspiracy theories that promise to restore order by providing an easy explanation and scapegoat towards which individuals can direct and rationalize their negative emotions.

The dissemination and spread of unsubstantiated rumors and/or conspiracy theories is one of the major challenges to disaster management during the initial post-disaster phase, because disaster misinformation can hamper recovery efforts by sowing distrust and confusion. Moreover, belief in such misinformation about the causes of natural disasters can lead people to support (or oppose) natural disaster mitigation and management policies that they might otherwise not if they possessed accurate information. As such, it is important to study both why people believe natural disaster misinformation and the consequences of such beliefs for public policy. The goal of this project, therefore, was to explore the following two questions: 1) what are the individual-level antecedents (and mitigating factors) of belief in natural disaster misinformation, and 2) what are the  consequences of belief in natural disaster misinformation for public policy attitudes.

We explored these questions in the context of the earthquakes that devastated cities across southern Turkey on February 6th, 2023. In the wake of the earthquakes, several conspiracy theories that blamed the United States for causing the earthquakes spread through the streets of Turkey and on social media (e.g., that the United States intentionally stimulated seismic activity that caused the earthquakes as a precursor to a U.S. invasion of Turkey, or that the earthquakes were caused by titanium alloy rods sent from U.S. satellites, or that U.S. oil explorers caused the earthquakes by inserting a bomb into an offshore oil well).  We conducted two surveys of nationally representative samples of 1,000 Turkish citizens each—one prior to the May 14, 2023 Turkish presidential election, and one after the election (in July 2023) to study the causes and consequences of these earthquake conspiracy theory beliefs.

In sum, we found that between 21% and 28% of Turkish citizens thought at least one of these conspiracy theories was probably or definitely true. With regard to antecedents, we found that people high in conspiratorial thinking (the predisposition to explain events in the world as the result of a conspiracy) and national narcissism (the belief that one’s nation is not receive the respect it deserves from other countries) were more likely to believe conspiracy theories that posited that the U.S. caused the earthquakes. Interestingly, people who lived near the earthquakes were not any more or less likely to believe the conspiracy theories than those who lived further away. We also found that people who trust scientists were less likely to believe the conspiracy theories. With regard to consequences, we found that people who believed in the anti-U.S. earthquake conspiracy theories were more supportive of the Turkish government's disaster preparedness and rescue/recover efforts, and less supportive of a change in those policies to improve preparedness in the future.

This project’s findings have substantive relevance for society and broader impacts. We found that a non-trivial percentage of the public believes natural disaster conspiracy theories, and that such beliefs can have significant negative consequences for democratic governance. More specifically, through a shift in the attribution of blame to external actors, belief in these conspiracy theories decreases the public’s willingness to focus “inward”—to hold the current government accountable for possible failures in disaster preparedness and/or management, thus likely reducing the calls for changes (both in leadership and policy) that might decrease the severity of natural disasters in the future. The importance of understanding the antecedents of these beliefs and their consequences is considerable for developing constructive ways to combat them. A more nuanced understanding of the antecedents of the belief in natural disaster conspiracy theories beliefs such as the ones this proposal discovered can inform scholars and policymakers interested in mitigating such beliefs and their effects.
